comment._content: Wow great photo! Can you imagine what those people must have thought? They would never have seen anything quite like this before.

comment.author: 72429059@N00
comment._content: I wouldn't be so sure - tanks were a popular spectacle in Lonodn in the latter years of WWI: www.flickr.com/photos/ridgway/145278027/

comment.author: 15338921@N00
comment._content: I see the tanks have their hatches up. In battle they were horrendously hot inside and the engine fumes could almost overcome the crew

comment.author: 48600109393@N01
comment._content: The thing that makes it for me is, perhaps predictably, the juxtaposition with the road sign: 'Caution, Drive Slowly'.

comment.author: 31324280@N02
comment._content:
Blighters, by Siegfried Sassoon:

The house is crammed: tier beyond tier they grin
and cackle at the Show, while prancing ranks
Of harlots shrill the chorus, drunk with din;
'We're sure the Kaiser loves our dear old Tanks!'

I'd like to see a Tank come down the stalls,
Lurching to rag-time tunes, or 'Home, sweet Home',
And there'd be no more jokes in Music-Halls
To mock the riddled corpses round Bapaume.

comment.author: 22971393@N07
comment._content: more men were killed and injured by carbon monoxide poisoning in tanks than by enemy action

comment.author: 71256895@N00
comment._content: It was also a hazard if you were in the tanks way whatever side you were on.  If you were injured there was no way to escape.

comment.author: 67307569@N00
comment._content: The two tanks in the foreground look like Mk IVs, and the one at the rear looks like a Medium Mark A Whippet.

comment.author: 31324280@N02
comment._content:
I am reliably informed that the two tanks are Mk V male (Home Service No. 502, and Mk V* female (home service No. 832). 502 has a later-style roof vent (just behind the roof silencer) as additional cooling for the tank interior. 832 has the unditching beams in place.
(Source: Great War Forum).
